prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We observe 13CO J=1-0, C18O J=1-0, CS J=2-1 and continuum emission centered at 99GHz in this science goal. We aim to resolve the ring component of RCW38 with 3" resoltuion. Molecular clumps in the ring observed with ASTE have sizses of larger than 40", and we therefore request ACA observations to recover large scale structures and all flux. Observations will be made toward a 137" x 261" area shown in Fingure 1 with 57 pointings with 12-m antennas and 22 pointings with 7-m ACA antennas. The continuum emission is also observed in the other science goal (Band3 N2H+ & HNC) at 103 GHz and 105 GHz to improve sensitivity.
Mopra C18O observations show typical Tmb temperature of 4K in the ring. We have no previous CS and 3-mm continuum studies on RCW38, so we refer studies in Orion. Line survey observations at 70GHz-115GHz toward Ori-KL with 0.2 pc resoltuion by Turner (1989) show the CS peak temperature of 3 K. CARMA 3-mm observations toward Ori-KL with 0.01 pc resolution show the peak intensity of ~30 mJy/beam with r.m.s noise level of 2 mJy/beam.
The present molecular ring has velocity widths (FWHM) of ~2-3 km/s. The minimum on-source time given by OT of 10 sec provides T(r.m.s) of 0.8 K and 1. K at 0.08 km/s (~35kHz) resolution at C18O and CS, respectively, which corresponds to 2.5 mJy at the 30 MHz bandwidth of the continuum observations. This is enough to detect emission above 3 sigma.

We observe N2H+ J=1-0, HNC J=1-0 and continuum emission centered at 103GHz and 105GHz in this science goal. We aim to resolve the ring component of RCW38 with 4" resoltuion. Molecular clumps in the ring observed with ASTE have sizses of larger than 40", and we therefore request ACA observations to recover large scale structures and all flux. Observations will be made toward a 137" x 261" area shown in Fingure 1 with 42 pointings with 12-m antennas and 13 pointings with 7-m ACA antennas. The continuum emission is also observed in the other science goal (Band 3 13CO, C18O & CS) at 99 GHz to improve sensitivity.
We have no previous N2H+, HNC and 3-mm continuum studies on RCW38, so we refer studies in Orion. Line survey observations at 70GHz-115GHz toward Ori-KL with 0.2 pc resoltuion by Turner (1989) show the N2H+ and HNC peak temperatures of 0.6 K and 8 K, respectively. N2H+ is expected to be stronger in RCW38 than Ori-KL because RCW38 is younger than ONC. CARMA 3-mm observations toward Ori-KL with 0.01 pc resolution show the peak intensity of ~30 mJy/beam with r.m.s noise level of 2 mJy/beam (Friedel et al. 2011).
The present molecular ring has velocity widths (FWHM) of ~2-3 km/s. The on-source time of 26 sec provides T(r.m.s) of 0.4 K at 0.08 km/s (~30kHz) resolution at N2H+, which is reduced to ~0.1 K at 0.8 km/s resolution. This also correspons to 1.4 mJy at 30 MHz bandwidth at the continuum obsrvations. This is enough to detect emission above 3 sigma even if N2H+ is as weak as Orion.

We observe NCN J=1-0, HCO+ J=1-0, H13CO+ and SiO v=0,1 J=2-1 in this science goal. We aim to resolve the ring component of RCW38 with 4" resoltuion. Molecular clumps in the ring observed with ASTE have sizses of larger than 40", and we therefore request ACA observations to recover large scale structures and all flux. Observations will be made toward a 137" x 261" area shown in Fingure 1 with 37 pointings with 12-m antennas and 13 pointings with 7-m ACA antennas. The continuum emission is also observed in the other science goal (Band 3 13CO, C18O & CS) at 99 GHz to improve the sensitivity.
We have no previous studies of these molecular transitions on RCW38, so we refer studies in Orion. H13CO+ shows the weakest peak intensity of 0.6 K among them in the Line survey observations at 70GHz-115GHz toward Ori-KL with 0.2 pc resoltuion by Turner (1989).
The present molecular ring has velocity widths (FWHM) of ~2-3 km/s. The on-source time of 34 sec provides T(r.m.s) of 0.36 K at 0.1 km/s (~35kHz) resolution at H13CO+, which is reduced to ~0.1 K at 0.8 km/s resolution. This is enough to detect emission above 3 sigma even if H13CO+ is as weak as Orion. Mopra provides a spatial resolution of 0.3 pc at RCW38, which is similar to those in the Turner survey in Ori-KL, and the 13CO and C18O intensities in RCW38 with Mopra are similar to those in the Turner survey, supporting that H13CO+ in RCW38 has also similar temperature as Ori-KL.

We observe 12CO J=2-1, 13CO J=2-1, C18O J=2-1 and continuum emission centered at 233GHz in this science goal. We aim to resolve the north part of the ring component of RCW38 with 1.6" resoltuion. Molecular clumps in the ring observed with ASTE have sizses of larger than 40", and we therefore request ACA observations to recover large scale structures and all flux. Observations will be made toward a 116" x 93" area shown in Fingure 1 with 68 pointings with 12-m antennas and 23 pointings with 7-m ACA antennas.
Mopra C18O J=1-0 observations show typical Tmb temperature of 2-4 K in the ring, and 12CO J=3-2/J=1-0 intensity ratio show the typical figure of over 1.0 and up to 1.5. CO J=2-1 intensity is therefore expected to be larger than that in CO J=1-0. CARMA 1-mm observations toward Ori-KL with 0.01 pc resolution show the typical intensity of ~100 mJy/beam with r.m.s noise level of 10 mJy/beam (Friedel et al. 2008).
The present molecular ring has velocity widths (FWHM) of ~2-3 km/s. The minimum on-source time given by OT of 10 sec, which provides T(r.m.s) of 0.6 K at 0.1 km/s (~70kHz) resolution at C18O, corresponding to 3 mJy at 30 MHz bandwidth in the continuum observation, is enough to detect emission above 3 sigma.

We observe 12CO J=2-1, 13CO J=2-1, C18O J=2-1 and continuum emission centered at 233GHz in this science goal. We aim to resolve the south part of the ring component of RCW38 with 1.6" resoltuion. Molecular clumps in the ring observed with ASTE have sizses of larger than 40", and we therefore request ACA observations to recover large scale structures and all flux. Observations will be made toward a 133" x 74" area shown in Fingure 1 with 73 pointings with 12-m antennas and 26 pointings with 7-m ACA antennas.
Mopra C18O J=1-0 observations show typical Tmb temperature of 2-4 K in the ring, and 12CO J=3-2/J=1-0 intensity ratio show the typical figure of over 1.0. CO J=2-1 intensity is therefore expected to be larger than that in CO J=1-0. CARMA 1-mm observations toward Ori-KL with 0.01 pc resolution show the typical intensity of ~100 mJy/beam with r.m.s noise level of 10 mJy/beam (Friedel et al. 2008).
The present molecular ring has velocity widths (FWHM) of ~2-3 km/s. The minimum on-source time given by OT of 10 sec, which provides T(r.m.s) of 0.7 K at 0.08 km/s (~61kHz) resolution at C18O, corresponding to 3 mJy at 30 MHz bandwidth in the continuum observation, is enough to detect emission above 3 sigma.

We observe 12CO J=3-2, 13CO J=3-2 and continuum emission centered at 333 GHz and 344 GHz towards proplyd candidates (DeRose et al. 2009) near the O5.5 star IRS2. The proplyds have sizes of 1" - 2" as shown by DeRose et al. (2009), and here we aim to resolve them at 0.6" resoltuion, which corresponds to 1000 AU at RCW38. The maximam recoverable scale in Band 7 is about 8", so we do not require ACA observations.
There are only few cases sutdying proplyds in high-J transitions of the CO emission. Sahai et al. (2012) observed a proplyd with Apex in CO J=3-2, resulting peak temperature of 1K and 0.4 in 12CO J=3-2 and 13CO J=3-2, respectively, and velocity width of ~3 km/s. 12CO is enough to measure the sizes, velocities and masses of the proplyds to achieve our goal, so we determine the on-source time focusing on 12CO. The on-source time of 3.07 min provides T(r.m.s) of 0.5 K at 0.1 km/s (~122kHz), which can be reduced to 0.17 K at 0.8 km/s, corresponding to 3 sigma detection for the half of the estimated temperature, ~0.5K. This also corresponds to 1 mJy at 30MHz bandwidth in the continuum observations. CARMA and SMA 1-mm continuum obsrvations toward proplyds in ONC is detected with an r.m.s. noise level of 2 mJy/beam (Eisner & Plambeck 2008). Our present on-source time meets this sensitivity.
According to OT, mapping observations toward the same 24" x 18" region shown by DeRose et al. (2009) is as fast as the single pointing observations towards each of the three prolyds, we thus choose mapping observations.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: RCW38 is an outstanding rich stellar cluster including 30 O stars with a total stellar mass of 10^4Mo in a small size of ~1pc. RCW38 is unique because it is extremely young with an age 0.5 Myrs and is located at only 1.7 kpc from the sun. The other rich cluster comparable is only the Orion Nebular Cluster (ONC). We recently found molecular gas surrounding RCW38 as a clear ring centered on the cluster indicating very recent ionization of the natal cloud. The total molecular mass of the cloud is ~10^4Mo, similar to the cluster mass, and the star formation seems extremely efficient. We here propose to use ALMA to obtain molecular gas distribution up to at ~1-4 arcsec with the aim to explore the distribution of clumps and filaments in the molecular gas. This will allow us to probe the physical condition of the natal/interacting molecular gas at much earlier evolutionary stage than in the ONC, and will revolutionize our knowledge on the rich cluster environment. This study will also promote our exploration of the solar system origin, which was possibly formed in such an environment.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Graduate School of Science, Nagoya University
